text: remarkable times in Saudi Arabia the
hugely influential Sunni Muslim Kingdom
there's been an unprecedented
anti-corruption purge with sweeping
arrests of senior politicians and
business leaders and members of the
royal family and a Saudi prince and
seven other officials had been killed in
a helicopter crash near the country's
border with Yemen where Saudi Arabia is
involved in a bitter civil war well to
help us understand all of this our
security correspondent Frank Gardner
joins us Frank what a weekend for the
kingdom let's just talk about these
purges first Mohammed bin Salman is seen
you know as a moderniser so just tell us
what all this means these are incredible
times inside Arabia there's never been
anything quite like it and in some ways
it's very exciting his supporters are
saying this is the man who's going to
lead us to the future who's setting the
stage for a modern economy and modern
society and jobs for all the millions of
scientists who were pouring out of
schools and universities others there
especially the older guard are extremely
worried by these these changes that are
happening very fast by Saudi standards
this is a country
unused to sudden change and he is
certainly amassing enemies amongst those
older god people what happened at the
weekend is that 11 senior Prince's
including Prince Alwaleed bin Talal were
detained they're not been thrown into
some dark dungeon they are reportedly
staying in great comfort of the Ritz
Carlton Hotel or another similar place
but the fact that they've been these
very high-profile establishment figures
have been removed and very important at
the head of the national guard Prince
mitat bin Abdullah has been removed
relieved of his command that removes at
a stroke the final obstacle to the crown
prince having total control over the
country now nominally it's his father
King Salman who's doing this he's the
king but he's 82 and everybody inside he
sees this as the hand of the very
ambitious dynamic and controversial
crown prince who's only 32 with very
little experience
it's extraordinary we're just getting in
the last few minutes the Attorney
General of Saudi Arabia saying that this
is just phase one indeed implying that
there's more to come
the idea that these people are really
the sort of spearhead of corruption in
Saudi Arabia I think is a little bit
hard to swallow because the way business
has been done by them is the way
business has been done by many many
people in Saudi Arabia at all levels for
a very long time it was ever thus the
arms deals in Saudi Arabia were always
done in the past in the form of
kickbacks in other words you're the
buyer I'm the seller and I pay rather
more than the inflated price you take
the difference that's what used to
happen in the past I can't say if it's
still happening today but certainly it's
a very opaque knot it's a very
untransparent economy now one of the
things that side is I think would like
to see is transparency in their own
government in terms of the oil income
there you never see an institute set of
accounts for that so if they're really
going to root out corruption
let's have transparency in government
that would be a shocking change
fascinating times in the kingdom Frank
as ever thanks so much for joining us
